items.promoHed: How to Make Hand-Shaped Pasta Any Night of the Week
items.body:
For as long as I can remember, I've fantasized about living in Italy. Eating pasta all day long, drinking wine all night long, harvesting in the vineyards sometime in between—I want the full Nonna lifestyle. But just because I dream in *Under-the-Tuscan-Sun*-Technicolor doesn't actually make me one of those Italian cooks who roll out handmade pasta without batting a sooty eyelash.

[#article: /articles/55fc4532cb84959337fd4663]||||||

Luckily, Epi's Editorial Assistant Sheela Prakash actually lived that life, spending four months working on a farm in Tuscany after college and then later attending graduate school in the oh-so-dreamy Tuscan hillside village of Bra. Listening to Sheela's stories of making fresh pasta, [incredible honey](http://www.epicurious.com/ingredients/how-to-cook-with-shop-bake-with-honey-article), and [eating her weight in garlicky pasta salad](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/italian-secret-great-pasta-salad-recipe-article), is almost, sort of, like being there myself.

But the thing that was most surprising? Just how often she still manages to make fresh pasta in her apartment kitchen now that she's back in New York. "If you can toss a few ingredients into a food processor and hit the pulse button a few times, then you can make fresh pasta," she assured me.

Encouraged, I went into the kitchen and started playing with dough. After several batches in the kitchen, I finally created a versatile dough that feels silky smooth in my hands and can easily be shaped into [long "pici" noodles](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/how-to-shape-fresh-long-pici-pasta-gallery), [orecchiette ears](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/how-to-shape-fresh-orecchiette-pasta-gallery), or [little cavatelli dumplings](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/how-to-shape-fresh-cavatelli-pasta-gallery), perfect for anytime my Nonna cravings come calling. 

Here's what I learned after making a few batches in the test kitchen:

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/55fc7a06393f29a26aca9195]||||||

+++

##The Food Processor Is Your Friend##
Most fresh pasta recipes (like ones from Italian cookbook legend Marcella Hazan and renowned Italian chef Jenn Louis), are a super-simple combination of [semolina flour](http://www.kingarthurflour.com/shop/items/king-arthur-semolina-flour-3-lb) (a yellow, more coarse wheat flour), all-purpose flour, salt, and water. Good. So the basic recipe is already easy. All I needed to do was make it *even easier.* Louis, who writes in her book [*Pasta By Hand*](http://www.amazon.com/Pasta-Hand-Collection-Regional-Hand-Shaped/dp/1452121885) about using a stand mixer to bring pasta dough together, gave me the idea to try using a food processor. And guess what? It works beautifully.

##Dough Needs to Be Kneaded (at least a little bit)##
The key to great pasta dough is creating a smooth, elastic dough that's not too sticky and not too dry. The key to that perfect texture? Giving your dough a few minutes of kneading time after it comes out of the food processor. Kneading the dough helps form the gluten that gives the pasta that al dente texture. 

[#recipe: /recipes/560013c2d296e7ab46e9db0e]|||
Pasta Dough for Handmade Shapes
|||

##You Don't Need Special Gear to Shape Your Pasta##
Not going to lie, even with my super-smooth pasta dough, I was really intimidated by hand-shaping it. Luckily, Sheela schooled me on some of the easiest shapes, starting with *pici*, which are basically [hand-rolled spaghetti noodles](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/how-to-shape-fresh-long-pici-pasta-gallery). (If you've ever played around with Play-Doh, it's likely you've made this shape.) Next we tackled [orecchiette](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/how-to-shape-fresh-orecchiette-pasta-gallery), which really just needs a quick twist of the thumb to make that classic "ear" shape. For [cavatelli](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/how-to-shape-fresh-cavatelli-pasta-gallery), Sheela showed me how to simply press my fingers into the dough, then drag them across the cutting board to make the hollowed shapes.

The shapes can take a little bit of practice to perfect. But when another batch of easy dough is just minutes away, I can practice all day. Just like Nonna would.

[#gallery: /galleries/55fb063a393f29a26aca8c7a]|||
How to Shape Fresh Orecchiette Pasta
|||

[#gallery: /galleries/55fb2823393f29a26aca8d8a]|||
How to Shape Fresh Long Pici Pasta
|||

[#gallery: /galleries/55fb2349393f29a26aca8d52]|||
How to Shape Fresh Cavatelli Pasta
|||

items.hed: Yes, You Need a Recipe for Instant Ramen
items.promoHed: The Korean Trick to Amazing Instant Ramen
items.body:
I know what you're thinking. A recipe for instant ramen? Don’t you just follow the directions on the package—boil water, dump in noodles and spice packets, and “stir occasionally”? 

For some, this vague and imprecise approach produces a satisfactory result. The noodles are warm, the broth is seasoned. But, as I found out when writing my cookbook, [Koreatown](http://www.amazon.com/Koreatown-A-Cookbook-Deuki-Hong/dp/0804186138), Koreans have a ramen process that makes for a better bowl.      

And Koreans should know. It's said that, on average, South Koreans eat 80 bags per person annually, which is a hell of a lot of instant noodles, and reason I look to the Koreans for instant ramen tutelage. Most of that ramen is [Shin Ramyun](http://www.nongshimusa.com/our-products/meal-noodle/shin-ramyun) (shin means “spicy” in Korean, and ramyun is the Korean word for ramen, a Japanese word). The following step-by-step directions for preparing a standard four-ounce package of ramen was developed with Shin, but it will work with Japanese, Chinese and Malaysian brands as well. 

####1. BOIL THE WATER, ADD THE SEASONING PACKETS####
Bring 2 ½ cups of water to a boil in a large saucepan over high heat. Add the soup base and vegetable mix. Boil for 1 minute. 

####2. DROP IN THE NOODLES—*GENTLY*####
Add the whole disc of dried noodles. *Do not break the noodles in half*. I know it’s fun to break stuff, but you must resist. Instead, slip the noodles into the boiling broth and press them down with chopsticks or a fork to keep them submerged. Don't stir the noodles—just keep them submerged. After 2 minutes, the noodles will soften and break apart. 

+++portrait-justified

[#image: /photos/56016cd38bed7b35040ac562]|||
Fanning ramen with a pot lid.
|||

+++

####3. FAN IT!####
This is critical: I find that simply boiling the noodles for 4-5 minutes, as most ramen directions read, produces a limp and soggy noodle. To avoid this, you have to slow down the noodle’s cooking process while the broth continues to cook. The best way to do this: fan the noodles. 

At the two minute mark, when the noodles have softened and come apart, pull the noodles from the broth and fan them for two minutes. The flow of air will stunt the cooking process, which gives the noodles a slightly more al dente texture. 

No [fan](https://www.etsy.com/market/hand_fan)? Forgot the first grade skill of making one out of paper? You can use a pot lid, or even your hand.

####4. PUT AN EGG ON IT####
Return the now-cooled noodles to the broth and add your toppings. Next week I'll go into the many, many ways to top instant ramen. For now, let's focus on the classic. Crack a raw egg over the noodles, cover the pot, and boil for 30 seconds. Turn off the heat, cover and let sit for 30 seconds more. Serve immediately.
items.seoTitle: How to Make the Best Instant Ramen
items.seoDescription: Step by step instructions on cooking instant ramen the best way.
items.socialTitle: The Korean Trick to Amazing Instant Ramen
items.socialDescription: One very unusual step makes the difference.

items.hed: How to Make the World's Greatest Spaghetti and Meatballs
items.dek: We spent hours in the Epicurious test kitchen developing a hearty tomato sauce and tender, flavorful meatballs. Sunday suppers will never be the same.
items.promoHed: 6 Steps to Achieving Spaghetti and Meatball Nirvana
items.body:
Even mediocre meatballs taste pretty good to me, but when the stars align and I taste a bowl of moist, robust meatballs; a well-balanced tomato sauce; and perfectly *al dente* pasta, the experience is downright transcendent. Happily, it turns out that achieving spaghetti and meatball bliss doesn't require an Italian grandmother or a trip to your favorite red sauce restaurant; it can happen at home. I know, because I've spent the past few weeks in the Epicurious test kitchen, creating the best-ever version of this comfort food classic.

I began by cooking batches of the six highest-rated spaghetti and meatball recipes on our site. After the kitchen team scrutinized what we liked (and didn't like) about each one, I headed back to the kitchen to create a [Frankenrecipe](http://www.epicurious.com/tag/frankenrecipe)—a recipe inspired by our favorite elements from each rendition. After several rounds of testing (trust me, no one around here complained), I created a recipe for [Our Favorite Spaghetti and Meatballs](http://origin.stag.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/our-favorite-spaghetti-and-meatballs-56389489). Here's what it entailed:

####Start with a Great Tomato Sauce####
The [tomato sauce](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/tomato-sauce-360149) recipe from The Frankies Sputino cookbook won our taste test with its concentrated tomato flavor and garlicky undertones. We used this recipe as a template for our version, but wondered if simmering the tomato sauce for 4 hours was truly necessary. After simmering batches of tomato sauce for 1, 2, 3, and 4 hours, my tasters were split over the 2-hour sauce (flavorful while maintaining a nice acidity from the tomatoes) and the 3-hour sauce (smooth, mellow, and sweet). (Personally, I think the sweet spot is at 2 1/2 hours.) The 1-hour sauce was underdeveloped; the 4-hour was too thick and muted for spaghetti and meatballs. A hit of red pepper flakes, dried oregano, and bay leaves enhances the tomato flavor and a healthy dose of basil leaves brings a little freshness at the end of simmering. 

####Find the Best Meat Blend####
Our taste test brought all kinds of meat blends to the table. We tried just ground beef, beef and pork (with and without veal), beef and bacon, and Italian sausage. A Gourmet recipe for [Spaghetti and Meatballs](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/spaghetti-and-meatballs-351190) provided our favorite combination of beef, pork, and veal, which also happens to be the most traditional mix for meatballs. The veal brings an unparalleled tenderness to the blend, but if you don't like veal or can't find it, simply increase the amounts of both the beef and pork. 

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/553a426605ebb68a358b9f17]|||
Mise en place ingredients for meatball testing.
|||

+++

####Incorporate the Right Breadcrumbs, Cheese, and Spices####
Breadcrumbs make a big difference in the texture of meatballs. We tried store-bought, fresh, as well as panko (Japanese breadcrumbs), but our favorite consistency came from day-old bread that's been torn and soaked in milk. Again, we have the Gourmet recipe for [Spaghetti and Meatballs](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/spaghetti-and-meatballs-351190) to thank for this revelation. The day-old (but not oven-dried or toasted) bread gives the meatballs a tenderness that we loved. 

We also tackled the cheese. Ricotta added moisture and tenderness, and pecorino added a salty sharpness, but we liked the approach of this [Bon Appétit recipe](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/spaghetti-and-meatballs-361349), which incorporates a healthy dose of parmesan.

As for seasoning, we knew we wanted to incorporate classic dried oregano and some heat from red pepper flakes. But what about a subtle background flavor that rounds out the whole dish? When we tried the [Classic Beef Meatballs](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/classic-beef-meatballs-369151) from the Meatball Shop Cookbook we knew we had found our secret flavor booster: ground fennel seeds. (We also added a little parsley, for freshness and color.) 

Pro tip: check the seasoning of your meat mixture *before* you start rolling your balls. Pinch off a bit of the mixture and brown it in some oil in a skillet. Taste for seasoning and add accordingly. This way you'll know your meatballs are perfectly seasoned before you cook the whole batch.

####Don't Pack Them Too Tightly####
Just like a burger, loosely packed meatballs have a more pleasant texture than ones that are packed too tightly. Use your hands to combine the meat mixture gently and don't overmix. Keep a bowl of cool water next to your work station to moisten your hands as needed. Roll the meat mixture into balls in between your palms (we like golf-ball sized balls for serving with spaghetti).

####Nail the Cooking Method####
These recipes were all over the map when it came to cooking method. Some were baked, some were simmered in sauce, but [others](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/spaghetti-and-meatballs-allamatriciana-356791) still used the cooking method I like the best: browning the meatballs in a skillet first, then simmering them in tomato sauce to cook through. Searing the meatballs caramelizes the outer surface and lends a richer flavor to the finished dish. 

####Don't Forget the Spaghetti!####
If you are putting this much love and care into your sauce and meatballs, make sure you treat your spaghetti right, too. Boil it in heavily salted water and undercook it ever so slightly. Don't forget to save some of the pasta water—it's gold for finishing your dish. Heat the pasta with some of the sauce (this is where you'll be glad you undercooked it a little), add a little cooking water to loosen, then let it soak up all the meaty glory.

[#recipe: /recipes/553a50a7ff11a7f13ba7b4f3]||||||

items.hed: 5 Fast Weeknight Pasta Sauces Every Cook Should Know
items.dek: Pasta with jarred sauce has always been a Wednesday night go-to dinner. But Wednesday night pasta with a fresh, homemade sauce? It's not crazy—it's crazy easy.
items.promoHed: How to Cook Pasta Faster Than Ever
items.body:
When it comes to weeknight pasta, I have a simple, iron-clad rule: The sauce shouldn't take longer to cook than the pasta itself does.

Don't get me wrong. I have nothing against pastas tossed with [long-simmered Bolognese](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/bolognese-sauce-107226). But that's weekend fare. On weeknights? Honestly, sometimes those nights are so hectic I barely have enough time to put some water on to boil and open a jar of sauce.

Except I've yet to find a jarred sauce I love. Which is how I started tinkering with fast weeknight sauces to begin with. 

It's a challenge to keep pasta sauces to just 15 minutes. But it inspires me to deploy every trick in my arsenal to maximize flavor in minimal time. And trust me—there's a *lot* of flavor you can pack into a 15-minute sauce. The five we created here all include a few special touches that take them from good to great—all in record time. 

+++landscape


[#image: /photos/55f7270a3c346243461d492d]||||||


text in callout


+++


####The 15-Minute Meat Sauce####
Most great ragùs gently simmer away on the stove for hours. Perfect for a lazy Sunday, but hardly a start-to-finish weeknight reality. Not too long ago I would’ve shook my head no at the idea that  meat sauce could be made in just 15 minutes, but this recipe proved me wrong. The splash of wine in this sauce (often used in long-cooking sauces, too) provides both flavor and a touch of sophistication. Using tomato paste in addition to tomato sauce—and giving the paste a quick fry before adding the liquid ingredients—deepens the tomato-y goodness and adds complexity. (Look for the extra rich double-concentrated stuff, sold in tubes.) A knob of butter stirred in at the finish adds just the right bit of richness. Pair this sauce with anything from short, chunky shapes, like penne, to long noodles, such as spaghetti or fettuccini. 

[#recipe: /recipes/55f7280b3c346243461d494c]|||
Pasta With 15-Minute Meat Sauce
|||

####The Cream Sauce####
Freshly grated lemon zest gives this unctuous ham- and pea-studded number a hit of bright flavor and a little flair. It's surprisingly light (since it's not thickened with flour), elegant enough for a dinner party, *and* a kid-pleaser—in other words, this sauce is a triple play. While farfalle is cream sauce's classic partner, orecchiette or any sort of twisty shape will offer lots of little places for bits of ham and peas to nestle.

[#recipe: /recipes/55f7288c3c346243461d4950]|||
Pasta with 15-Minute Ham, Pea, and Cream Sauce
|||

+++landscape


[#image: /photos/55f726b3e7f5be0c7ccb6e75]||||||


text in callout


+++


####The Pesto####
This silky basil pesto has a couple of tricks up its sleeve. Oil, garlic, and pine nuts are puréed until thick and creamy *before* the basil is added. This means less time in the machine for the tender herb, which helps the sauce keep its emerald green color and fresh, bright taste. A toasted pine nut topping, plus a little Parm and fresh basil at the finish, give this pasta extra class. 

[#recipe: /recipes/55f70963e7f5be0c7ccb6df7]|||
Pasta with 10-Minute Pesto
|||

####The Burst Tomato Sauce####
Cherry tomatoes blister and burst when cooked in hot olive oil, and their sweet juices caramelize to form this sumptuous sauce. While tender-skinned cherry tomatoes are at their peak in summer through late fall, they are generally available (and surprisingly good) year-round. A sprinkle of basil and a shower of freshly grated Parm make for a fabulous finish. 

[#recipe: /recipes/55f7086fe7f5be0c7ccb6df5]|||
Pasta with 15-Minute Burst Cherry Tomato Sauce
|||

+++landscape


[#image: /photos/55f726b33c346243461d4928]||||||


text in callout


+++


####The Garlic and Oil Sauce####
*Aglio e olio* ("garlic and oil") is the ultimate pantry pasta, a simple sauce you can count on when fridge is empty. But you don't need to be desperate to make this version, which gets an extra lift from anchovies, spicy red-pepper flakes, and crispy toasted breadcrumbs. Spaghettini (thin spaghetti) makes for good twirling and provides a nice balance between sauce and pasta, but traditional spaghetti works just as well.

[#recipe: /recipes/55f709053c346243461d4906]|||
Pasta with 15-Minute Garlic, Oil, and Anchovy Sauce
|||

items.hed: Fast #WeeknightPastas for Crazy, Hectic Nights
items.dek: If it's a busy night, a lazy night, or just one of those nights when you *cannot deal*...well, then, it's a pasta night.
items.promoHed: Fast, Fresh Pasta Dinners Crazy, Hectic Nights
items.seoDescription: Fast and simple weeknight pasta recipes.
items.socialDescription: If it's a busy night, a lazy night, or a hectic night...well, then, it's a pasta night.
items.body:
Have you heard? Epicurious is all about [#WeeknightPasta](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/epicurious-pasta-week-article) this week. (And every week, for that matter. But this week especially.) Because there's nothing faster or more satisfying than pasta—nothing, that is, except pasta you can execute with no fuss, no drama, and almost no time. Such as these five pastas right here: 

####Monday: Lazy Linguine####
Don’t have time to make a creamy alfredo? Well, obviously—*it's Monday*. Try this quick burst tomato linguine instead. It's livelier than a lot of other sauces out there, thanks to plenty of chilis.

[#recipe: /recipes/54a41f2d19925f464b377406]||||||

####Tuesday: No-Cook Tomato Night####
Nothing against, you know, *cooking*, but sometimes [it’s even better to not cook at all](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/how-to-make-one-pot-no-cook-summer-pasta-article). And since tomatoes are going to be gone in about two minutes, the time to make this no-cook tomato-and-mozz sauce is *now*.

[#recipe: /recipes/54a4204419925f464b377c20]||||||

####Wednesday: Instant Gemelli####
For those nights when you can’t even bother to find the colander. This gemelli is all one-pot and doesn’t require draining. Bring everything to a boil, and the water will reduce into a silky sauce.

[#recipe: /recipes/55a804032165ea177986eb30]||||||

####Thursday: Cacio e Pepe####
Congratulations. You’ve almost reached the weekend, which may mean two things: 1) you’re exhausted. 2) your refrigerator’s looking bare. Luckily, this simple *cacio e pepe* (literally cheese and pepper) is here to save your night. 

[#recipe: /recipes/54a426166529d92b2c00b941]||||||

####Friday: Ricotta Gnudi####
Why handmade dumplings on a Friday night? Because you love yourself. Pair these plump ricotta numbers with lots of red sauce or lots of [brown butter](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/how-to-make-brown-butter-gallery).

[#recipe: /recipes/54a41eee19925f464b377233]||||||

fields.caption: Linguine with Burst Tomatoes and Chiles
fields.promoTitle: Linguine with Burst Tomatoes and Chiles
fields.title: Linguine with Burst Tomatoes and Chiles

items.hed: Welcome to Pasta Week
items.dek: Five days of pasta intel you can really sink your teeth into (because it's *al dente*).
items.body:
When we first talked about dedicating a week at Epicurious to pasta (a Pasta Week, if you will), it seemed like a no-brainer. Of *course* we should do a series of stories celebrating pasta. After all, there's no other food we turn to as instinctively and automatically as those Italian noodles. Too tired to cook something fancy? Make some pasta. Need something to eat while watching *The Voice*? Make some pasta. Nothing in the fridge? Two words: [pantry pasta](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/pasta-with-15-minute-garlic-oil-and-anchovy-sauce-56390061). 

But the more we thought about the stuff, the more we realized how deep our pasta habits really run. Sometimes we turn into pasta zombies, mindlessly making the same old sauce week after week. We had a hunch that even when it comes to something as easy as weeknight pasta, there's a lot to learn. 

And learn we did. We learned how to make an [amazingly delicious meat sauce](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/fast-easy-pasta-sauces-weeknights-article)—that tastes like it took all day to simmer—in just 15 minutes. We learned how [one simple ingredient](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/top-your-pasta-with-breadcrumbs-article) can transform almost any plate of pasta. And we learned how to make a homemade pasta [without ever messing with dough](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes-menus/how-to-make-simple-two-ingredient-fresh-pasta-article).

And that's just the beginning. We're going to share pasta intel every day this week, and we hope you'll do the same. Tag shots of your pasta dinners with #weeknightpasta on Instagram and Twitter, and tell us how you like your pasta. Odds are, we'll like it, too. It's pasta, after all.
items.seoDescription: An introduction to Epicurious Pasta Week.

fields.title: Pasta with Grilled Tomato and Scallion Sauce

items.hed: Does Quinoa Need to Be Rinsed?
items.dek: We're often warned to wash the trendy grain, but one expert says it may not be necessary.
items.promoHed: Do You *Really* Need to Rinse Your Quinoa?
items.body:
Cooks who want to eat trendy grains—and yes, there is such a thing as a trendy grain—have one question they come up against again and again: Does quinoa need to be rinsed before cooking?

The whole debate started thanks to saponin, a naturally occurring chemical that coats every tiny grain of quinoa. It's there for good reason—to ward off insects—but it has a strong, unpleasant taste. Rinsing the quinoa gets rid of the saponin and thus its bitter flavor—great. But rinsing quinoa is also annoying. It also makes toasting your quinoa impossible—unless you want to wait hours and hours for your quinoa to dry.

The good news is that grain expert and [cookbook author](http://www.amazon.com/Simply-Ancient-Grains-Flavorful-Recipes/dp/1607745887), and [avid Instagrammer](https://instagram.com/mariaspeck/) Maria Speck doesn't think rinsing is necessary. 

"I almost never rinse my grains," Speck says. "I’ve been eating grains my whole life, and I’ve never seen such clean grains as the ones sold today."

Much of the quinoa that is sold in the States is pre-washed before it's packaged (brands often slap the term "pre-washed" on the bag itself). But that's a little misleading. "It’s often not washed with water," Speck says. Rather, the quinoa has "undergone an abrasion process" that removes the saponin. 

The "clean" quinoa does comes with a nutritional cost, though. The abrasion process "shaves off a bit of the beneficial bran layer and germ from each kernel," Speck says. That makes the quinoa slightly less nutritious than it would be otherwise.

"Still, it's still a very nutritious grain," says Speck—and knowing that I don't have to rinse it first means I'll probably cook even more of it than I used too.
items.seoTitle: Does Quinoa Need to Be Rinsed?
items.seoDescription: Do you need to rinse quinoa before cooking?
items.socialTitle: Does Quinoa Need to Be Rinsed?
items.socialDescription: The truth about preparing the world's trendiest grain.

items.hed: The Italian Secret to Great Pasta Salad
items.dek: How one tip from a Tuscan farm cook changed our pasta game forever.
items.promoHed: The Italian Secret to Great Pasta Salad
items.body:
The summer after I graduated college I put off being a real person and ran off to Tuscany to intern on an organic farm. It was a perfect four months: I planted. I harvested. I ate double my weight in the best Italian food I've ever tasted.

That food was prepared by the farm's cook, a woman named Graziella. As is the Italian way, pasta was often at the center of the table. But on those hot, Tuscan afternoons in late July, when the temperature inched up to 100 ºF, not even the Italians wanted hot bowls of pasta. So Graziella made pasta salad instead. 

But Graziella's pasta salad didn't taste like the many I'd eaten at backyard barbecues here in the States. There was an undertone to them, a background flavor that was in every bite, but was hard to identify.

When I finally cobbled together enough Italian to ask Graziella how she made her pasta, I realized what I was tasting: garlic. But not minced or crushed or sliced garlic. No, Graziella used the *essence* of garlic. And she found that essence in just one clove, which she rubbed on the inside of the bowl that she'd eventually be tossing the pasta in.

Now I use garlic *essence* too. This is how it's done: Grab a bowl (it doesn't matter whether it's wood, glass, or even plastic), peel a garlic clove, halve it, and rub the cut side of each half all over the inside surface of the bowl. Throw in vegetables like chopped tomatoes or summer squash, and add a handful of fresh herbs, some salt, and some pepper. Add some just-cooked, still-warm pasta to the bowl and toss with the vegetables and herbs, drizzling with olive oil as you go. The olive oil-dressed pasta will pick up the garlic juices in the bowl, coating every strand in a gentle dose of sweet, garlicky flavor. Eat the pasta while it's still warm or wait until it's a more cookout-friendly room temperature—either way, Graziella would approve.

[#recipe: /recipes/54a4204419925f464b377c20]|||
Pasta with Tomatoes and Mozzarella
|||
items.seoTitle: The Italian Secret to Great Pasta Salad
items.seoDescription: How one clove of garlic can change an entire bowl of pasta.
items.socialTitle: The Italian Secret to Great Pasta Salad
items.socialDescription: How one little trick we picked up in Tuscany makes all the difference.

items.hed: The Ingredient Scrambled Eggs Are Always Missing
items.dek: If this isn't in your eggs, you're doing it wrong.
items.promoHed: How to Scramble the Right (Read: Cheesy) Way
items.body:
When people ask you how you like your scrambled eggs, they're really asking one thing: Soft and buttery or firm and fluffy? I'm not here to convince you of the virtues of one or the other. After all, how you take your eggs is like your social security number. Your fingerprint. Your astrological sign. It's *you*. 

But while I won't tell you how to take your eggs, I will tell you what to put in them: cheese.

That's right. Most scrambled eggs are missing some cheese. And it makes no sense. Why should omelets have all the fun? omelets usually aren't the best carrier for cheese anyway. All too often, that cheese remains an unmelted block within that log of egg. And even if it does melt, you're still biting into alternating mouthfuls of egg and cheese. 

A cheesy scramble, on the other hand, merges cheese and egg into a creamy, harmonious whole. It's all of the joy of an omelet, none of the stress. And with just a few pointers, you'll find yourself making flawless cheesy scrambles every morning.

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/55fb1dfad0f4806d25847027]||||||

+++

####Prep a great cheese####
Eggs cook fast, so you probably want to grate your cheese before you turn on the stove. That way, you'll be able to add your cheese without worrying about your eggs overcooking as you mess with the grater. Depending on how cheesy you like your eggs, you'll need 1 to 2 tablespoons of cheese for every two eggs you're scrambling. Parmesan, ricotta, Monterey Jack, pecorino—pretty much any cheese will be delicious, except for especially mild cheese like mozzarella and especially pungent ones like blues.

####Add it halfway through####
Resist the urge to add your grated cheese to your bowl of beaten eggs. The optimum time to add the cheese is halfway through scrambling (over medium-low heat), when the eggs are just starting to form curds as you push them around in the pan with a spatula. That way, the cheese has just enough time to melt without overheating.

####Finish with a flourish####
Once your eggs are the way you like them, get them out of that pan—they'll keep on cooking in there, even with the stove turned off. Once they hit your plate, finish them off with a bit of something extra, like a bit more grated cheese, some chopped herbs, or just some freshly ground pepper. After all, they're cheesy eggs. They deserve it.

[#recipe: /recipes/54a4092f6529d92b2c003854]|||
Soft Scrambled Eggs with Fresh Ricotta and Chives
|||

items.hed: How to Make the World's Best Cheeseburger, Using Magic
items.dek: Smashed cheeseburgers, like the ones you get at Shake Shack or Smashburger, aren't made from magic. They only look that way.
items.promoHed: Magical Video of a Delicious Cheeseburger Cooking Itself
items.body:
Whenever I see someone in our test kitchen cook, I feel like a little kid watching a magician. It starts with that boring bit of set up, some waving hands, a few wiggling fingers. But then—presto-change-oh!—a joyous food miracle appears. 

Like this smashed cheeseburger, [our version of the Shack Shake burger](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/how-to-make-shake-shack-burger-at-home-epicurious-secrets-article) that's sweeping the country right now. You won't believe how a semi-frozen hunk of meat, a poofy bun, and some yellow cheese slices morphs magically into the kind of cheeseburger that's so good, you need to find a place to hide so no one sees you shamefully wolf down the second one. 

I'd give you the secrets of, say, how a super-chilled piece of meat gets even crispier and juicier when you smash it with a piano. Or how a tomato slices itself when you touch it with your knife like a wand. Or what words you need to say to get a secret sauce to instantly appear in a bowl. But part of the fun is learning the trick. So, pay close attention to the video and watch it a few times. 

But don't tell anyone else the secret. It's magic.


[#recipe: /recipes/54c7b571e231becc7f3df367]||||||
